unnormalised: Planning a corporate event in India involves careful consideration of dates and timings. Many organizations prefer to schedule events avoiding major festivals. For instance, holding a key product launch close to Diwali, falling on 01/11/2024, might reduce attendance due to employee travel and festive commitments. Similarly, scheduling anything major during the monsoon season, esp. in cities like Mumbai in July, can present logistical nightmares.
normalised: Planning a corporate event in India involves careful consideration of dates and timings. Many organizations prefer to schedule events avoiding major festivals. For instance, holding a key product launch close to Diwali, falling on the first November two thousand and twenty four, might reduce attendance due to employee travel and festive commitments. Similarly, scheduling anything major during the monsoon season, especially in cities like Mumbai in July, can present logistical nightmares.

unnormalised: Another key factor is aligning with auspicious days and timings, as per Indian tradition. While not mandatory, acknowledging these can be appreciated. Consulting a 'panchang' (Hindu calendar) can help identify suitable dates and times. Events starting at, say, 11:00 AM on an auspicious day might be seen favorably. Remember to prepone deadlines if a public holiday, like 26/01, falls close by, to avoid delays.

unnormalised: Time zones also play a crucial role if you’re catering to a pan-Indian audience. Scheduling webinars or conferences at 2:00 PM IST might be ideal for attendees in Delhi and Mumbai, but those in Guwahati will find it starts at 2:30 PM, while participants in some international locations will be inconvenienced. Consider recording the event for those unable to attend live.
normalised: Time zones also play a crucial role if you’re catering to a pan-Indian audience. Scheduling webinars or conferences at two P M I-S-T might be ideal for attendees in Delhi and Mumbai, but those in Guwahati will find it starts at two thirty P M, while participants in some international locations will be inconvenienced. unnormalised: Finally, factor in daylight saving time (DST) if coordinating with international teams, even though India doesn’t observe it. Ensure all communications clearly state the time zone (e.g., 09:00 AM PST) to avoid confusion. Confirm the meeting time a day before, say on 14/03, to remind attendees and address any scheduling conflicts. This will help ensure a successful and well-attended event.
